content.description: Starts sitting to the right of the small roof and passes to the left under the roof, up the left side of the roof and back around the top of the roof to connect with either a high ball finish or a good jump down point. Crux is passing under the roof on the left and reaching the top of the roof, requires a tricky finger jam and a tiny crimp with limited footholds, mostly smears after you come out from under the roof.
content.protection: Can be set up as a top rope from a solid tree if you want to top out the climb, the very top of the boulder is around 25 feet.
content.location: Continue driving down FS 136 past the waterfall for approximately half a mile until you see a very obvious and very large granite boulder on the right side of the road. Park at on the left side of the road below the boulder. Approach hike is around 100 feet.

content.description: Edgy and sometimes slick basalt with small but stong holds. in and near the crack has some loose stuff to beware of but nothing serious. crux is about 20 feet up when holds get small and reachy and ends at the large horizontal crack.
content.protection: No bolts yet but great boulders and a tree to use for building TR anchors, bring lots of webbing or static rope and equalize off of the two large boulders.
content.location: Park at the second cattle guard you come to near the large powerlines and follow a bouldered off trail to the top of the wall and the anchor spots. Either scramble down the slate to the right or bring rope protection and rappel in after you build your TR. Starts to the left of the waterfall and follows the crack up.

content.description: Large, deep canyon that parallels the I-17 as it descends into the Verde Valley from the south. Running water in bottom (small stream, bring a filter if you want to drink it) and a relatively driveable road labeled as FS 136 leading to a short foot approach. High clearance vehicles recommended but my buddy did it in a Subaru.
